Award.AwardTitle: Biomechanicsof Self-Assembly of the Lepidopteran Feeding Device
Award.AbstractNarration: The overarching goal of this project is to understand the biomechanical principles of proboscis self-assembly and to apply these principles to engineer fiber-based self- assembling microfluidic devices for manipulation of micro and nano droplets. The model system under investigation is the proboscis feeding tube of butterflies. This tube is assembled and hardened after emergence of the adult from the pupal encasement by joining dorsal and ventral galeae fibers and cuticle hardening. The mature proboscis is coiled but can be fully extended during the feeding process; the extension involves antiparallel sliding of the galeae fibers. The goals of the project are (i) to study the effect of saliva in creating capillary pressure that forces the two galeae together (the elasto-capillary effect) in live butterflies and a model system of fiber rails, (ii) to study saliva behavior during this process of proboscis assembly, using X-ray phase-contrast imaging, (iii) to provide full characterization of mechanical and wetting properties of the proboscis to evaluate the model parameters and assess the applicability of different self-assembling and hardening scenarios, and (iv) to develop a fiber-rail type microfluidic system that that relies on capillary action and would work on the principles of proboscis assembly/disassembly.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Self-assembly of a butterfly proboscis is an excellent example demonstrating how cooperative interactions of elasticity, wettability, adhesion, and capillary effects evolve at different scales to form a highly complex micro- and nanofluidic system. Our rigorous experimental and theoretical study involved unique X-ray imaging and optical microscopy of live butterflies, augmented with the mechanical and physico-chemical characterization of proboscis materials, and supported by modeling.

 For more than 150 years, the proboscis has been regarded as a solid tube allowing the liquid food to enter only from the distal end. The experimental and theoretical results of this project convincingly showed that the drinking straw model has no solid ground and that the proboscis is a multifunctional fiber-based device that can splay the galeal tips apart, slide them one over the other and contract/expand the tube radially. These results changed the textbook knowledge and call for re-examination of the existing scenarios of lepidopteran evolutionary diversification. We discovered that the galeae constituting the united proboscis can be moved on demand to change the intergaleal gap and the pores in the linking mechanisms. The biological and physical investigation and experimentation of proboscis assembly revealed the phenomenon of proboscis self-repair.

The second level of the mouthpart assembly involves design of the sucking pump/proboscis pair. We discovered a fundamental link between the Stefan law of viscous adhesion of the moving pistons in the sucking pumps with the Poiseuille law of friction for flows in the adjacent conduits. The discovered Stefan-Poiseuille link controls development of insects mouthparts as well as engineered micro and nanofluidic pumps.

 The elasto-capillary effect was studied in detail to reveal an unexpected link between the theory of capillarity with the field theory, in particular, with the Born-Infeld 2D electrodynamics. New morphological transitions of droplets on complex-shaped proboscises have been discovered; the gained knowledge was applied to the man-made shaped fibers.

 We successfully fabricated artificial proboscises, based on the insights and ideas gained from these studies of the natural feeding devices of biological organisms. We modeled and developed magnetic fiber-based grabbers that are able to perform as artificial proboscises with a controlled positioning of their tips, using a magnetic field.

Within this project, we began developing a new Magnetic Rotational Spectroscopy method for rheological analysis of nanoliter droplets of lepidopteran saliva and hemolymph. This methodology also has broader applications in chemistry, biology, atmospheric physics, materials science, and bioengineering and as a tool for studying rheologically complex nanoliter droplets and micron-thick films when other methods fall short.

The collaboration among biologists, materials scientists, and engineers enabled the application of these fundamental findings to engineering problems related to the development of artificial proboscises for probing minute amount of fluids. The work laid the groundwork for establishing a model of successful interactions between researchers working in life sciences and engineering.

This project generated groundbreaking discoveries that challenged common textbook knowledge. It provided broad public interest, evident from the media coverage.

Our project has involved a total of 23 students (high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels). Students successfully defended their MS (2) and PhD dissertations (1). Undergraduates and high school students regularly participated in the research. This project ignited the interest of a broad scientific community and attracted the attention of a diverse community of biologists, chemists, physicists, and engineers.
